newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: IMF opposes unpegging Lithuania litas now.
newsitem.headline: IMF opposes unpegging Lithuania litas now.

text.p: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Wednesday it was against unpegging Lithuania's currency from the dollar but may discuss it in future.
The right-wing Homeland Union party, which came first in elections at the weekend, wants to end the four-to-one peg of the litas currency to the dollar.

"We are willing to discuss this issue with the new government but would not support a hasty exit from the currency board before the proper conditions were in place for such a move and the conditions do not exist now," Domenico Fanizza, Lithuania's IMF resident representative, told Reuters.
The Homeland Union's prime minister-designate Gediminas Vagnorius said earlier he wanted to end the fixed exchange rate.
Vagnorius, who met today an IMF mission visiting Lithuania, wants to do this by ending the currency board system under which the litas is kept at the peg.
The central bank guarantees the peg by having enough reserves in its vaults exactly to back the currency in circulation.
But it has none of the powers of a normal central bank such as the ability to intervene in the foreign exchange market, to change interest rates or to alter banks' capital reserve requirements.
